facts.text: Messrs N. Jivanlal Co. had free hand in dealing with petitioner's licences; petitioner received commission.

facts.text: Central Government refused to interfere on September 22, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner then moved the Central Government against this, order but on September 22, 1955, the Central Government refused to interfere.

facts.text: Collector of Customs ordered auction of goods on March 31, 1956.

facts.text: Petition No. 571 of 1954 heard on March 24, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: This petition had companye before this Court for hearing on March 24, 1955. Shri K. R. Chaudhury appeared for the petitioner before this Court.

issues.text: Whether the Union of India and other respondents to the petition have acted in contempt of this Court

anchor.surface_text: Union of India and other respondents to the petition have acted in contempt of this Court and appropriate action should, therefore, be taken by us against the said respondents.

issues.text: Whether the policy enunciated in the Press Note dated February 3, 1955 and Public Notice No. 25-ITC PN 56 dated June 30, 1956 amounts to a monopoly violating the petitioner's fundamental right to carry on trade and business

holdings.text: The prayer for a writ in respect of the alleged contempt made by the petitioner in Petition No. 423 of 1956 is thoroughly unjustified and wholly irresponsible.

anchor.surface_text: We have no hesitation in holding that the prayer for a writ in respect of the alleged contempt made by the petitioner in this petition is thoroughly unjustified and, we regret to add, wholly irresponsible.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No undertaking given by Solicitor-General for time-bound disposal; order unambiguous, providing one month for SLP after communication of revisional order; mere hope expressed, not binding.

holdings.text: The policy enunciated in the Press Note dated February 3, 1955 and Public Notice No. 25-ITC PN 56 dated June 30, 1956 does not amount to a monopoly violating Article 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this petition is also entirely misconceived and there is no substance in the contention raised by the petitioner. It is hardly necessary to emphasize that, in modern times, the export and import policy of any democratic State is bound to be flexible.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Import/export policy flexible for national needs like foreign exchange, protecting industries; canalisation regulates distribution to avoid price fluctuations, not monopoly; petitioner not established importer.

holdings.text: Article 32 jurisdiction cannot be invoked to direct revalidation of expired import licences or challenge factual findings of authorities leading to confiscation.

anchor.surface_text: But it is difficult to understand how the petitioner can invoke the jurisdiction of this Court under Art. 32 of the Constitution for obtaining this relief. We do not propose to discuss this matter elaborately because, in our opinion, the position in law is abundantly clear.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 32 not for directing exercise of administrative discretion or re-examining factual conclusions; if grievance against erroneous findings, remedy by suit for damages, not writ.

holdings.text: Jurisdiction under Article 32 not appropriately invoked for reliefs against customs orders and licence invalidation as they involve factual disputes.

anchor.surface_text: However, since the petitions purport to invoke the jurisdiction of this Court substantially under Art. 32 of the Constitution, it is necessary to deal with the relevant points in disposing of these petitions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitions raise factual issues like trafficking, not pure legal questions affecting fundamental rights warranting writ relief.

holdings.text: Imports and Exports (Control) Act, 1947 applies to soda ash requiring import licence; s.3(1)(a) covers goods of any specified description disjunctively.

anchor.surface_text: s. 3 which is the same as r. 84, sub-r. 3 , of the Defence of India Rules... We must, therefore, hold that the argument that no licence was required for the import of soda ash and so all the orders passed by the appropriate authorities in regard to the confiscation of the consignments are invalid must fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Omission of r.84(2) Defence of India Rules not releasing soda ash; s.3(1)(a) read disjunctively includes import of specified goods; effectively covers prior rule; goods deemed prohibited/restricted under Sea Customs Act s.19.

holdings.text: Section 3 of Imports and Exports (Control) Act, 1947 is valid, not excessive delegated legislation.

anchor.surface_text: challenge to the validity of legislative enactments on the ground of delegated legislation... Unfortunately for Shri Umrigar his challenge to the validity of the impugned section under the Imports and Exports Act is completely covered by the decision of this Court in Harishankar Bagla v. The State of Madhya Pradesh.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Policy in preamble to continue powers for essential supplies/public interest; guidance from predecessor Defence of India Act; follows Harishankar Bagla upholding similar Essential Supplies Act provisions.

holdings.text: Finding of trafficking in licences by authorities based on legal evidence, not quashable.

anchor.surface_text: conclusion of the relevant authorities that his client was trafficking in licences is based on no legal evidence... In the present case, it is impossible to accede to the assumption that there is no legal evidence against the petitioner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Circumstances like poor finances (Rs.15,000 capital for Rs.50L licence), conduct, role of unlicensed N. Jivanlal Co., false allegations constitute legal evidence; not 'no evidence'.
